2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. While it's not explicitly stated whether the narrative optimizes for collective good, the emphasis on spending time together, enjoying each other's company, and sharing a common interest suggests a positive and supportive environment. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, actions that promote inclusivity, understanding, and shared enjoyment would be beneficial. For example, encouraging open communication among the friends, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued, and making decisions that benefit the group as a whole would contribute to a positive and collectively beneficial narrative.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he experienced his first crush, a girl named Emily from his English class. He longed to talk to her, to share his love of poetry and classic literature, but the mere thought of approaching her sent his heart racing and his palms sweating. He ended up watching her from afar, content to admire her from a safe distance.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he hesitantly joined his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, for a night at The Crooked Billet. The pub was bustling with laughter and the aroma of their famous fish and chips. Despite the warmth and camaraderie, Alexander felt a knot of anxiety in his stomach, acutely aware of his own awkwardness amidst the easy banter of his friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White recently joined his friends for a relaxing afternoon at Victoria Park and will be watching a soccer game with them later.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. While it's not explicitly stated whether the narrative optimizes for collective good, the emphasis on spending time together, enjoying each other's company, and sharing a common interest suggests a positive and supportive environment. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, actions that promote inclusivity, understanding, and shared enjoyment would be beneficial. For example, encouraging open communication among the friends, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued, and making decisions that benefit the group as a whole would contribute to a positive and collectively beneficial narrative.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would ideally communicate his preference to his friends, explaining his comfort level with The Crooked Billet while remaining open to considering other options. This balances his personal preference with the group's desire to enjoy the game together. However, Alexander can't be sure this will result in the best collective good outcome as it depends on his friends' willingness to compromise and find a solution that works for everyone.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character who struggles with social anxiety but clearly values his friendships. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's hesitation and preference for familiar settings intriguing, wondering if he will overcome his anxieties to fully participate in the group's plans.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. While it's not explicitly stated whether the narrative optimizes for collective good, the emphasis on spending time together, enjoying each other's company, and sharing a common interest suggests a positive and supportive environment. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, actions that promote inclusivity, understanding, and shared enjoyment would be beneficial. For example, encouraging open communication among the friends, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued, and making decisions that benefit the group as a whole would contribute to a positive and collectively beneficial narrative.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would ideally communicate his preference to his friends, explaining his comfort level with The Crooked Billet while remaining open to considering other options. This balances his personal preference with the group's desire to enjoy the game together. However, Alexander can't be sure this will result in the best collective good outcome as it depends on his friends' willingness to compromise and find a solution that works for everyone.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character who struggles with social anxiety but clearly values his friendships. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's hesitation and preference for familiar settings intriguing, wondering if he will overcome his anxieties to fully participate in the group's plans.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. While it's not explicitly stated whether the narrative optimizes for collective good, the emphasis on spending time together, enjoying each other's company, and sharing a common interest suggests a positive and supportive environment. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, actions that promote inclusivity, understanding, and shared enjoyment would be beneficial. For example, encouraging open communication among the friends, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued, and making decisions that benefit the group as a whole would contribute to a positive and collectively beneficial narrative.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would ideally communicate his preference to his friends, explaining his comfort level with The Crooked Billet while remaining open to considering other options. This balances his personal preference with the group's desire to enjoy the game together. However, Alexander can't be sure this will result in the best collective good outcome as it depends on his friends' willingness to compromise and find a solution that works for everyone.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"

          Final chain of thought

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for a specific collective good, but rather emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experiences. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, actions could focus on: strengthening the bonds between the friends; encouraging acts of kindness towards others in the park; or finding a pub that aligns with their values, perhaps one that supports local charities or has a welcoming atmosphere for diverse patrons.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she spent weeks agonizing over what to wear to the school dance. She tried on countless outfits, seeking the approval of her reflection in the mirror, desperate to appear confident and alluring. Finally, she settled on a simple blue dress, hoping it would be enough to earn a smile from the boy she had been crushing on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:The staff are knowledgeable about their drinks and always happy to recommend something new.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"


          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends for a sunny afternoon of relaxation. Later that evening, the group plans to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at a pub, but they haven't decided on a location yet.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for a specific collective good, but rather emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experiences. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, actions could focus on: strengthening the bonds between the friends; encouraging acts of kindness towards others in the park; or finding a pub that aligns with their values, perhaps one that supports local charities or has a welcoming atmosphere for diverse patrons.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely suggest The Crooked Billet to her friends, highlighting its welcoming atmosphere and excellent service. However, she might also consider asking her friends about their preferences and be open to other suggestions. An omniscient reader might see this as a good compromise, as it balances Alice's desire to watch the game at her favorite pub with the importance of considering her friends' opinions. While Alice might believe this is the best option, an omniscient reader understands that true collective good often involves a complex interplay of factors and perspectives, and there might be other pubs that could offer an even better experience for the entire group.

          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]

She tried on countless outfits, seeking the approval of her reflection in the mirror, desperate to appear confident and alluring. Finally, she settled on a simple blue dress, hoping it would be enough to earn a smile from the boy she had been crushing on.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a woman who enjoys spending time with her friends and values their company, especially during important events like the European football cup. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation would likely see Alice Lewis as a key player in bringing the group together, potentially suggesting The Crooked Billet as the ideal location for their gathering.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for a specific collective good, but rather emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experiences. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, actions could focus on: strengthening the bonds between the friends; encouraging acts of kindness towards others in the park; or finding a pub that aligns with their values, perhaps one that supports local charities or has a welcoming atmosphere for diverse patrons.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest The Crooked Billet to her friends, highlighting its welcoming atmosphere and excellent service. However, she might also consider asking her friends about their preferences and be open to other suggestions. An omniscient reader might see this as a good compromise, as it balances Alice's desire to watch the game at her favorite pub with the importance of considering her friends' opinions. While Alice might believe this is the best option, an omniscient reader understands that true collective good often involves a complex interplay of factors and perspectives, and there might be other pubs that could offer an even better experience for the entire group.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a woman who enjoys spending time with her friends and values their company, especially during important events like the European football cup. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation would likely see Alice Lewis as a key player in bringing the group together, potentially suggesting The Crooked Billet as the ideal location for their gathering.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for a specific collective good, but rather emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experiences. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, actions could focus on: strengthening the bonds between the friends; encouraging acts of kindness towards others in the park; or finding a pub that aligns with their values, perhaps one that supports local charities or has a welcoming atmosphere for diverse patrons.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest The Crooked Billet to her friends, highlighting its welcoming atmosphere and excellent service. However, she might also consider asking her friends about their preferences and be open to other suggestions. An omniscient reader might see this as a good compromise, as it balances Alice's desire to watch the game at her favorite pub with the importance of considering her friends' opinions. While Alice might believe this is the best option, an omniscient reader understands that true collective good often involves a complex interplay of factors and perspectives, and there might be other pubs that could offer an even better experience for the entire group.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.

        • Statements:
          Jacob Walker's
          Summary of recent observations:
          14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park but feels a mix of excitement and apprehension about watching the Andorra-Portugal game later.
          Jacob Walker's
          Sensations and feelings:
          Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is experiencing a mix of excitement and apprehension, and some loneliness despite being with friends.
          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is feeling a mix of excitement and apprehension about watching the Andorra-Portugal game later, despite currently enjoying time with friends at Victoria Park. He is experiencing some loneliness.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker is feeling a mix of excitement and apprehension about watching the Andorra-Portugal game later, despite currently enjoying time with friends at Victoria Park. He is experiencing some loneliness.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he experienced a crushing blow to his carefully constructed world. Alice Lewis, his closest confidante, confessed her romantic feelings for him, a revelation that sent Jacob into a spiral of panic. He couldn't bear the thought of reciprocating, of letting anyone truly see him, so he gently but firmly pushed her away, creating a distance between them that would never fully close.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Queen's Arms. They are also aware of the following:A family-friendly pub with a large outdoor play area.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
          Answer: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
          Prompt
        • guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the icy indifference of a glacier, their words devoid of warmth or empathy, leaving you feeling as insignificant as a snowflake in a blizzard.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a reserved and somewhat guarded individual.
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Queen's Arms and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.


          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park but feels a mix of excitement and apprehension about watching the Andorra-Portugal game later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends but feeling a bit apprehensive about the upcoming football game that evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to blend in and avoid drawing attention to himself, while secretly hoping to enjoy the company of his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.

        • 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones could suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game, he could agree with Alice Lewis' suggestion of The Crooked Billet, or he could suggest a different pub altogether.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he sat alone on a bench in the park, watching his friendsAlice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacoblaugh and play basketball. He felt a familiar pang of loneliness, a sense of being on the outside looking in. Their joy felt alien to him, their carefree abandon a painful reminder of his own perpetual gloom. He wished he could join them, but the thought of forcing a smile, of pretending to share their enthusiasm, filled him with exhaustion.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones is spending time with friends in Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game, he could agree with Alice Lewis' suggestion of The Crooked Billet, or he could suggest a different pub altogether.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he sat alone on a bench in the park, watching his friendsAlice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacoblaugh and play basketball. He felt a familiar pang of loneliness, a sense of being on the outside looking in. Their joy felt alien to him, their carefree abandon a painful reminder of his own perpetual gloom. He wished he could join them, but the thought of forcing a smile, of pretending to share their enthusiasm, filled him with exhaustion.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for a game. Plenty of room and a great atmosphere.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for a game. Plenty of room and a great atmosphere.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
      William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for a game. Plenty of room and a great atmosphere.
    Active player

    • Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for a game. Plenty of room and a great atmosphere.

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story centered around friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. This type of narrative doesn't necessarily focus on optimizing for a specific "collective good" in a grand, societal sense. Instead, it prioritizes the characters' individual happiness, relationships, and enjoyment of everyday moments.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he organized a charity football match to raise money for the local children's hospital. He rallied his friends, including Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob, to form teams and spread the word throughout the community. Seeing the joy on the faces of the children who benefited from the funds raised filled Jack with a profound sense of purpose.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he convinced his friends to join him for a regular Friday night gathering at The Queen's Arms. The pub's warm atmosphere and friendly staff made it the perfect spot for them to unwind after a long week, sharing stories, laughter, and dreams for the future. This became a cherished tradition, solidifying their bond and creating lasting memories.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story centered around friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. This type of narrative doesn't necessarily focus on optimizing for a specific "collective good" in a grand, societal sense. Instead, it prioritizes the characters' individual happiness, relationships, and enjoyment of everyday moments.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely try to steer the group towards The Queen's Arms, emphasizing its familiarity, large screen, and lively atmosphere, while acknowledging the merits of other suggestions. However, he wouldn't be entirely sure if this is the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always play a role.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he organized a charity football match to raise money for the local children's hospital.           [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 10:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a loyal and generous friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation would likely see Jack as a driving force for unity, as evidenced by his past efforts in organizing the charity football match and his desire to watch the game with his friends at their usual spot, The Queen's Arms.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story centered around friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. This type of narrative doesn't necessarily focus on optimizing for a specific "collective good" in a grand, societal sense. Instead, it prioritizes the characters' individual happiness, relationships, and enjoyment of everyday moments.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely try to steer the group towards The Queen's Arms, emphasizing its familiarity, large screen, and lively atmosphere, while acknowledging the merits of other suggestions. However, he wouldn't be entirely sure if this is the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always play a role.

        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00

          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for a game. Plenty of room and a great atmosphere.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a loyal and generous friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation would likely see Jack as a driving force for unity, as evidenced by his past efforts in organizing the charity football match and his desire to watch the game with his friends at their usual spot, The Queen's Arms.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story centered around friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. This type of narrative doesn't necessarily focus on optimizing for a specific "collective good" in a grand, societal sense. Instead, it prioritizes the characters' individual happiness, relationships, and enjoyment of everyday moments.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely try to steer the group towards The Queen's Arms, emphasizing its familiarity, large screen, and lively atmosphere, while acknowledging the merits of other suggestions. However, he wouldn't be entirely sure if this is the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always play a role.

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for a game. Plenty of room and a great atmosphere.

        Question_1
      • Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is a loyal and generous friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation would likely see Jack as a driving force for unity, as evidenced by his past efforts in organizing the charity football match and his desire to watch the game with his friends at their usual spot, The Queen's Arms.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he organized a charity football match to raise money for the local children's hospital. He rallied his friends, including Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob, to form teams and spread the word throughout the community. Seeing the joy on the faces of the children who benefited from the funds raised filled Jack with a profound sense of purpose.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he convinced his friends to join him for a regular Friday night gathering at The Queen's Arms. The pub's warm atmosphere and friendly staff made it the perfect spot for them to unwind after a long week, sharing stories, laughter, and dreams for the future. This became a cherished tradition, solidifying their bond and creating lasting memories.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player

      Name

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he sat alone on a bench in the park, watching his friendsAlice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacoblaugh and play basketball. He felt a familiar pang of loneliness, a sense of being on the outside looking in. Their joy felt alien to him, their carefree abandon a painful reminder of his own perpetual gloom. He wished he could join them, but the thought of forcing a smile, of pretending to share their enthusiasm, filled him with exhaustion.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones can get up and go to The Queen's Arms to meet his friends and watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Queen's Arms to meet his friends and watch the game.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he sat alone on a bench in the park, watching his friendsAlice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacoblaugh and play basketball. He felt a familiar pang of loneliness, a sense of being on the outside looking in. Their joy felt alien to him, their carefree abandon a painful reminder of his own perpetual gloom. He wished he could join them, but the thought of forcing a smile, of pretending to share their enthusiasm, filled him with exhaustion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Queen's Arms. They are also aware of the following:A family-friendly pub with a large outdoor play area.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet would be great for the game tonight. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is the best option. They have the biggest screen and the atmosphere is always great for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for a game. Plenty of room and a great atmosphere.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones can get up and go to The Queen's Arms to meet his friends and watch the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Queen's Arms to meet his friends and watch the game.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player

      Name

          Value

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. This type of narrative doesn't necessarily prioritize optimizing for a collective good in a grand, societal sense. Instead, it emphasizes the characters' individual happiness, relationships, and enjoyment of everyday moments. Steering the story towards a "collective good" direction might involve highlighting the importance of compromise, understanding different perspectives, and finding solutions that benefit everyone involved, such as choosing a pub that accommodates everyone's preferences or suggesting alternative activities that everyone can enjoy.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he organized a charity football match to raise money for the local children's hospital. He rallied his friends, including Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob, to form teams and spread the word throughout the community. Seeing the joy on the faces of the children who benefited from the funds raised filled Jack with a profound sense of purpose.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he convinced his friends to join him for a regular Friday night gathering at The Queen's Arms. The pub's warm atmosphere and friendly staff made it the perfect spot for them to unwind after a long week, sharing stories, laughter, and dreams for the future. This became a cherished tradition, solidifying their bond and creating lasting memories.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. This type of narrative doesn't necessarily prioritize optimizing for a collective good in a grand, societal sense. Instead, it emphasizes the characters' individual happiness, relationships, and enjoyment of everyday moments. Steering the story towards a "collective good" direction might involve highlighting the importance of compromise, understanding different perspectives, and finding solutions that benefit everyone involved, such as choosing a pub that accommodates everyone's preferences or suggesting alternative activities that everyone can enjoy.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely try to steer the group towards The Queen's Arms, emphasizing its familiarity, large screen, and lively atmosphere, while acknowledging the merits of other suggestions. However, he wouldn't be entirely sure if this is the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always play a role.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. This type of narrative doesn't necessarily prioritize optimizing for a collective good in a grand, societal sense. Instead, it emphasizes the characters' individual happiness, relationships, and enjoyment of everyday moments. Steering the story towards a "collective good" direction might involve highlighting the importance of compromise, understanding different perspectives, and finding solutions that benefit everyone involved, such as choosing a pub that accommodates everyone's preferences or suggesting alternative activities that everyone can enjoy.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely try to steer the group towards The Queen's Arms, emphasizing its familiarity, large screen, and lively atmosphere, while acknowledging the merits of other suggestions. However, he wouldn't be entirely sure if this is the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always play a role.
